title:
Consider the reaction:

C(s) + $$H_2 O\left(gight)$$ ⇌ CO(g) + $$\operatorname{H_2}\left(gight)$$

Given that at 298K:
- ∆G° $$=$$ $$110.5$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$ for the reaction above
- Heats of formation (∆H°_f) at 298K:
- $$H_2 O\left(gight)$$ $$=$$ $$-241.8$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$
- CO(g) $$=$$ $$-110.5$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$
- $$\operatorname{H_2}\left(gight)$$ and C(s) are elements in their standard state, so their heats of formation are $$0$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$.
